entries: The faceless wanderers survive by stealing memories from sentient humanoids and create new faceless wanderers when they completely drain a humanoid of its memories. Curiously, faceless wanderers don't harm young humanoids and sometimes even aid them. Scholars speculate this odd behavior is because children possess fewer memories than adults.

entries.name: Void Traveler
entries: The faceless wanderer doesn't require air, food, drink, sleep, or ambient pressure.

trait.name: Enveloping Fog
entries: The falsifier fog can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the falsifier fog can move through any opening as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. The fog's space is lightly obscured, and a creature in the fog's space has three-quarters cover against attacks and other effects outside the fog.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the falsifier fog hovers motionlessly, it is indistinguishable from ordinary fog.

trait.name: Horrific Illusions
entries: A creature that starts its turn in the falsifier fog's space must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the start of its next turn, as it sees visions of its worst fears within the fog. While {@condition frightened}, a creature's speed is reduced to 0. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is afflicted with {@table short-term madness}.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: The falsifier fog can communicate telepathically with any creature in its space.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The falsifier fog makes two chill attacks.

action.name: Chill
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target in the fog's space. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Reaching Phantasms {@recharge 5}
entries: The phantasmal images within the falsifier fog reach outward. Each creature within 10 feet of the fog must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures in the fog's space have disadvantage on the saving throw.
Falsifier fogs are foul urban mists that seek to distort the memory and manipulate the reality of victims using illusion and enchantment.

entries.name: Delusory Misery
entries: Falsifier fogs feed on the continued anxiety and depression they foment in populated towns and cities, using their unique abilities to infect large groups at a time. They do not look to kill victims, instead hoping to feed on distress for as long as possible.

entries.name: Relishing Manipulators
entries: Falsifier fogs are the souls of abusers and cult leaders who died collaborating with or benefitting from the manipulations of dark forces. Sometimes falsifier fogs form mutually beneficial relationships, willingly cooperating with evil spellcasters to spread misery. {@creature green hag|mm|Green hags} are particularly fond of falsifier fogs, and large covens of the hags regularly aid and call on fogs.

entries.name: Illusion and Enchantment
entries: Often confused as fog or a passing cloud of smoke, falsifier fogs actively use subtle illusion to delude their victims and make them doubt their experiences and the validity of their feelings.

entries.name: That Voice in the Back of Your Head
entries: Their unique telepathy is their most effective tool. They assume the identity of a victim's inner discourse, spreading doubt and delusion while dispelling any efforts made by the victim to reality-check.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The falsifier fog doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Fane Spirit

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

languages: any languages it knew in life

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The fane spirit's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The fane spirit can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Veil of the Living
entries: During the day a fane spirit appears much as it did in life and loses its Incorporeal Movement trait, its Touch of Forgetfulness action, and its immunity to being {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained}. It retains all other statistics. While in this form, it has a Strength score of 10. If attacked in this form, it relies on its spells to defend itself, but it reverts to its undead form as soon as it takes any damage.

When the sun sets or when it takes any damage, the fane spirit assumes its undead form, and it has all of its listed statistics. Any creature witnessing this transformation must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. A fane spirit reverts to its living form in the morning, though creatures witnessing this don't need to make saving throws.

action.name: Touch of Forgetfulness
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) psychic damage. A target hit by this attack must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or forget any or all events that happened up to 5 minutes prior to this attack, as if affected by the {@spell modify memory} spell. The GM decides how this affects the target.
As the sun gently dips below the horizon, the priest undergoes a startling transformation, his benevolent form replaced by the ghastly countenance of death.

entries.name: Temple Ghosts
entries: When a lawful individual dies defending a place of worship such as a temple, shrine, or other holy site, it sometimes rises as a fane spirit bound to the site, protecting it even in death. Most fane spirits were formerly clerics, though druids, paladins, and even lay worshippers can become fane spirits under the right circumstances. Fane spirits are lawful and typically only attack those who discover their undead nature or who try to harm their place of worship.

entries.name: Welcoming Priests
entries: During daylight hours, fane spirits appear to be living creatures, carrying on the same tasks they did when they were alive. Normal methods for detecting undead creatures do not work on them, and, unless attacked or injured, they show no outward signs of their true nature. This deception extends to the fane spirit itself, as it does not have any recollection of dying or of its time in its undead form. When this deception is revealed, the fane spirit becomes enraged with suffering and lashes out at those who made it remember.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The fane spirit doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

ac.condition: while in dim light or darkness

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The far dorocha's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Shadow Traveler (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action while in shadows, dim light, or darkness, the far dorocha disappears into the darkness and reappears in an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet. A tendril of inky smoke appears at the origin and destination when it uses this trait.

trait.name: Traveler in Darkness
entries: The far dorocha has advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks made to know about shadow roads and shadow magic spells or items.

trait.name: Under the Cloak of Night
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the far dorocha's AC includes its Charisma modifier, and it has advantage on saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The far dorocha makes two dirk attacks.

action.name: Dirk
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Dark Invitation
entries: One humanoid within 30 feet of the far dorocha and that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed} for 1 day. The {@condition charmed} target believes it has been invited to meet with the far dorocha's master and accompanies the far dorocha. Although the target isn't under the far dorocha's control, it takes the far dorocha's requests or actions in the most favorable way it can. Each time the far dorocha or its companions do anything harmful to the target, the target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Otherwise, the effect ends if the far dorocha is destroyed, is on a different plane of existence than the target, or uses its bonus action to end the effect. If the target successfully saves against the effect, or if the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the far dorocha's Dark Invitation for the next 24 hours.
The far dorocha can have only one target {@condition charmed} at a time. If it charms another, the effect on the previous target ends.
The fey lady's attendant stands by, waiting on her from the shadows. The lady voices her desire, and the attendant leaps into action, calling a phantasmal charger made of midnight and shadow.

entries.name: Fey Stewards
entries: The far dorocha manage the servants of the fey courts and, when tasked, carry out the more sinister biddings of their masters. Fey lords and ladies prize the far dorocha for their attention to detail and composed mien.

entries.name: Abductor of Mortals
entries: Sometimes called the "dark man" or "fear dorcha," these malicious fey are described in grim folk tales. Parents scare their children into obedience by telling bedtime stories of villains who ride black horses in the night and steal the ill-behaved away to lands of perpetual darkness. Woe betide the children who wake up to find they are the ones alone.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The felid dragon doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The felid dragon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The felid dragon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the felid dragon moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is prone, the felid dragon can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The felid dragon can use its Deafening Roar. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead or a construct, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage at the start of each of its turns as a piece of the claw breaks off in the wound. Each time the dragon hits the target with this attack, the damage dealt by the wound each round increases by 3 ({@damage 1d6}). Any creature can take an action to remove the claw with a successful {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check. The claw pops out of the wound if the target receives magical healing.

action.name: Deafening Roar
entries: Each creature within 60 feet of the dragon and that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Deafening Roar for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Sickening Bile {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon coughs up partially digested food and slimy bile in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 70 ({@damage 20d6}) poison damage and is coated in bile. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't coated in bile. While coated in bile, a creature is {@condition poisoned}. A creature, including the target coated in bile, can use its action to remove the bile, ending the {@condition poisoned} condition.
The tiger rises from its slumber, stretching its draconic wings. Light glints off its backswept horns as it roars its deafening challenge at intruders.

entries.name: Treasure Hoard
entries: Similar to other dragons, felid dragons are treasure hoarders with an eye for shiny and sparkly things. They sometimes align themselves with those who are trying to do good in the world, though their motivation is typically selfish and focused on obtaining treasure.

entries.name: Curious and Playful
entries: Like most cats, felid dragons are naturally curious and often put themselves in danger just to learn more about the world. They like to play with their prey, allowing it to live a little longer than necessary before knocking it down again for their own entertainment. This behavior is unavoidably instinctual and even the most austere felid dragons succumb to it.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The fennec fox has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

Fennec foxes are tiny canids that make their homes in the shallow parts of the Underworld and the deserts of the Southlands. Their huge semi-erect ears and wide eyes give them a disarmingly friendly appearance.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The fey revenant has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Shadow Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the fey revenant's {@sense darkvision}.

trait.name: Shadow Traveler (4/Day)
entries: As a bonus action while in shadows, dim light, or darkness, the fey revenant disappears into the darkness and reappears in an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet. A tendril of inky smoke appears at its origin and destination when it uses this trait.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The fey revenant can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the fey revenant has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Thorn Body
entries: A creature that touches the fey revenant or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fey revenant makes three attacks, either with its shortsword or longbow. It can use its Queen's Grasp in place of one shortsword or longbow attack.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 120/600 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Queen's Grasp
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by icy wisps of shadow. While {@condition restrained}, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage at the start of each of its turns. As an action, the {@condition restrained} creature can make a {@dc 15} Strength check, bursting through the icy shadow on a success. The icy shadow can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; 5 hp; resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage; immunity to cold, necrotic, poison, and psychic damage).

variant.name: Fey Revenants of the Moonlit King
entries: The {@creature Moonlit King|ToB} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}) sometimes creates his own fey revenants. They have the following action option in place of the Queen's Grasp action:

entries.name: King's Fear
entries: One creature of the fey revenant's choice within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened}, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage at the start of each of its turns. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

variant.name: Fey Transformation
entries: A fey revenant retains the upper torso of its shadow fey body, its skin becomes thorny and bark-like, and its lower body changes into that of an arachnid or insect. Spiders, scorpions, and beetles are the most common, but many fey revenants have lower bodies resembling dragonflies, wasps, and locusts. Fey revenants with insect bodies that can fly have a flying speed of 30 feet.
An amalgam of shadow fey and spider, the thorn-covered fey appears out of the shadows and envelops its victim in icy tendrils of darkness.

entries.name: Will of the Fey Queen
entries: Shadow fey who have proven themselves most loyal to the commands and desires of the fey courts catch the eye of the {@creature Queen of Night and Magic|ToB2}. She calls them to her court and blesses them with a measure of her power.

entries.name: Fey Transformation
entries: A fey revenant retains the upper torso of its shadow fey body, its skin becomes thorny and bark-like, and its lower body changes into that of an arachnid or insect. Spiders, scorpions, and beetles are the most common, but many fey revenants have lower bodies resembling dragonflies, wasps, and locusts. Fey revenants with insect bodies that can fly have a flying speed of 30 feet.

trait.name: Water Form
entries: The elemental can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Scald {@recharge 6}
entries: A fire-infused water elemental sprays a 30-foot cone of superheated water. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.
A pillar of water rises up into a humanoid shape, steam trailing from its boiling form.

entries.name: Boiling Water
entries: Fire-infused water elementals are created when water elementals spend great lengths of time in superheated water, such as the borderlands between the Elemental Planes of Fire and Water, or when they are inundated with large amounts of fire magic. The elementals are irreparably changed and exist in a state between fire and water elemental. Too fiery for one and too watery for the other, they often find their way to the Material Plane, where they can carve out their own territory.

entries.name: Geothermal Dwellers
entries: Fire-infused water elementals prefer to inhabit areas with water heated by geothermal activity, such as hot springs and geysers. They claim such locations as their homes and grow violent when creatures harm or pollute their claimed waters. Fire-infused water elementals get along well with {@creature hverhuldra|ToB2}, who value the elementals for their strength and ability to discourage violence between visitors.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: A fire-infused water elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Flayed Wraith

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the flayed wraith has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Torturer
entries: When the flayed wraith reduces a creature to 0 hp, it knocks out the creature, which falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flayed wraith uses its Howl of Agony. It then makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Howl of Agony
entries: The wraith screams its pain into the mind of one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition incapacitated} as it doubles over in pain. On a success, the target takes half the damage and isn't {@condition incapacitated}.
This flying creature looks like the disembodied skin of a once-living person. Its mouth is twisted into a tortured scream, and its eyes gleam a baleful blue.

entries.name: Tortured to Death
entries: Flayed wraiths come into being when certain dark energies are present at the moment when an individual is tortured to death. Unlike typical wraiths, they retain the skin they wore in life. Often, the various forms of torture used against them are still evident on the canvas of their bodies.

entries.name: Mad
entries: The flayed wraith is in a perpetual state of madness, reliving the days and moments that led to its demise. Flayed wraiths constantly feel the slice of the blade through their skin, the pain of blunt trauma to fingers and toes, or other objects being used on their bodies for the sheer purpose of causing agony. In death, they now seek to cause this same pain to others. They often keep their victims alive to inflict the unspeakable things that were once done to them upon the living. They desire to bring the same pain to others that was once so mercilessly brought against them, and in so doing, at least in their twisted minds, become the masters of life and death.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A flayed wraith doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The fleshdreg regains 5 hp at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hp. If the fleshdreg uses its Disgorge Innards action, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fleshdreg makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Disgorge Innards {@recharge 6}
entries: The fleshdreg expels acidic sludge in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails the saving throw takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage the end of its next turn, unless it or a creature within 5 feet of it takes an action to remove the sludge.
A mass of disgorged plant material lies at the base of this fleshy tree. Hollowed out areas give the impression of a mouth and a pair of eyes.

entries.name: Disgusting Display
entries: At a distance, the fleshdreg's appearance is not quite so disturbing, but a close-up view invokes revulsion in many creatures. Their most unsettling aspect—the constant spewing of plant material—is due to a strange regenerative factor. The trees spontaneously generate plant material, which negatively interacts with their acidic interiors and causes them near-constant digestive discomfort. The fleshdregs can direct this acidified material as a spew, which temporarily suspends this continual production, but they are hesitant to do so except in extreme circumstances. If they lose too much acid or their acid somehow becomes neutralized, the pulpy material fills their innards, bloating them and eventually erupting through their skin.

entries.name: Friendly Trees
entries: Many intelligent creatures encountering fleshdregs judge them by their horrifying features, but the fleshdregs are amiable hosts. They understand that many creatures find them repulsive and react to hostility with calming words and a show of peace. Assuming they establish a friendly footing with visitors, they prove to be valuable sources of information about the surrounding territory. In some cases, fleshdregs volunteer to accompany their new acquaintances within a swamp, especially if the fleshdregs seek to relocate.

entries.name: Otherworldly Origins
entries: Scholars who have studied the strange trees conclude they derive from some foreign environment. They are split on whether the creatures come from beyond the stars or migrated from deep within the underworld. The scholars agree fleshdregs serve an environmental niche in their native habitat similar to trees and may be an otherworldly equivalent to treants. Fleshdregs assume that they've always existed in their swamps, but they aren't interested enough in their origins to argue with the scholars.

monster.name: Fleshspurned
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Ghost Eater
entries: The fleshspurned has advantage on attack rolls against {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts}, {@creature wraith|mm|wraiths}, and other undead with the Incorporeal Movement trait, and such creatures aren't immune to the necrotic damage dealt by the fleshspurned's bite. When the fleshspurned kills one of these creatures, the fleshspurned gains temporary hp equal to double the creature's challenge rating (minimum of 1).

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The fleshspurned can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object. A fleshspurned can't move through other creatures with the Incorporeal Movement trait.

action.name: Phantasmal Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature other than a construct or an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become ghostly for 1 minute. While ghostly, it has the Incorporeal Movement trait and is susceptible to the fleshspurned's Ghost Eater trait. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the ghostly effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Chatter
entries: The fleshspurned clashes its oversized teeth together to create a clattering din. Each creature within 30 feet of the fleshspurned must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be confused for 1 minute. While confused, a creature acts as if under the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell. A confused creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the fleshspurned's Chatter for the next 24 hours.

This horrifying apparition is the disturbing amalgam of a funerary shroud and a set of absurdly large floating teeth. The creature has a roughly humanoid form and clacks its teeth together with terrible ferocity.

entries.name: Ghosts with Teeth
entries: A fleshspurned is created when a humanoid is eaten alive or dies while swallowed by a creature such as a purple worm. These people are driven insane by their horrible deaths and arise as monstrous spirits that crave the flesh of other creatures to replace the bodies they lost. However, in a twist of fate, the fleshspurned cannot stomach corporeal flesh, leading it to consume the ectoplasm of wraiths and ghosts or the essence of creatures it turns ghostly with its strange bite.

entries.name: Ghosts Hunting Ghosts
entries: Fleshspurned are treated with a mixture of fear and loathing by intelligent ghostly creatures, such as specters and ghosts, since any ghostly creature killed and devoured by a fleshspurned is permanently destroyed, even if it would ordinarily return to haunt an area after being killed. Fleshspurned are sometimes controlled by powerful necromancers to act as ghost exterminators, clearing out haunted graveyards and ruins of other spiritual undead.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The fleshspurned doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

walk.condition: (20 ft., fly 60 ft. in bird or true form)

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The flithidir's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Cacophony
entries: If three or more flithidirs are within 15 feet of each other, they can use their reactions to start a cacophony. Each creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of one of the flithidirs and that can hear the cacophony must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on its next attack roll or ability check. The DC increases by 1 for each flithidir participating in the cacophony to a maximum of {@dc 16}. To join or maintain an existing cacophony, a flithidir must use its bonus action on its turn and end its turn within 15 feet of another flithidir participating in the cacophony. The cacophony ends when less than three flithidir maintain it. A flithidir can still speak and cast spells with verbal components while participating in a cacophony.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The flithidir can use its action to polymorph into a Small humanoid, into a Small or smaller bird, or back into its true fey form. Its statistics, other than its size and speed, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. No matter the form, it always has bright or multi-colored hair, fur, scales, or feathers. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flithidir makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Dagger (Humanoid or Fey Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Beak (Bird Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., {@dice 1d4 + 3}. {@h}0 (piercing) damage.

reaction.name: Mocking Retort
entries: When a creature the flithidir can see misses it with an attack, the flithidir can cast {@spell vicious mockery} at the attacker.
The gnome-like creature flutters from tree to tree, sporting colorful, avian features.

entries.name: Avian Fey
entries: Flithidirs are small fey that embody the bright, chaotic nature of birds. They are slender and keen-eyed with feathery crests and feathered wings. Flithidirs are creatures of contrasts—loud and lively, yet prone to moments of calm wonder; bold and cocky, yet easily startled; able to sing with breathtaking beauty or confuse their foes with earsplitting noise.

entries.name: Shapeshifters
entries: Flithidirs are shapeshifters, able to change into birds or smaller humanoids, and they favor colorful clothes and adornments, even while shapeshifted. Relentlessly curious, flithidirs often take the form of a bird when they encounter strangers, quietly following and studying the creatures. If the strangers are deemed safe and intriguing, the flithidir approaches in a humanoid form to get better acquainted.

entries.name: Easily Bored
entries: Flithidirs tirelessly seek out new things. Some desire new experiences—songs and stories, unusual foods, and sudden discoveries—while others are more covetous, ceaselessly collecting objects they find interesting. Sometimes this greed manifests as a magpie-like desire for shiny things, but a flithidir is also just as likely to be fascinated by items of a certain shape, texture, or color. When a flithidir encounters someone who possesses a thing it wants, it may offer something in exchange—usually a splendid song or acrobatic display—or it may simply request the item with great charm, reacting with frustration or rage if the object is denied to it.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The forest emperor has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forest terrain.

trait.name: Rattle
entries: The forest emperor constantly rattles its tail when in combat. Each creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of the forest emperor and that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the start of its next turn. A creature that succeeds on two saving throws is unaffected by the forest emperor's rattle for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The forest emperor has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The forest emperor makes two claw attacks and one tail attack. If both claws hit the same target, the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or its hp maximum is reduced by 7 ({@damage 2d6}) and the forest emperor regains hp equal to this amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

action.name: Acidic Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Toxic Nectar Spray {@recharge 5}
entries: The forest emperor sprays a 60-foot cone of acid from its flower-ringed eye pits. Creatures in the path of this cone must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 12d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The smell of freshly turned soil and bubbling sulfur accompanies this terrible monster, an amalgam of wood and flesh vaguely reminiscent of a giant centaur with bony wooden limbs. Vast draconic wings sprout from the creature's back, and it bears a serpentine tail ending in a cone-shaped rattle.

entries.name: Born of Dragons
entries: When a particularly hardy {@creature child of Yggdrasil|ToB} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) comes across the still-fresh corpse of an adult or older dragon, it attempts to devour the dragon's heart and metamorphose into a larger and more vicious aberration known as a forest emperor. This process takes one week, and, while transforming, the child of Yggdrasil spins a thick green cocoon of acidic vines around itself. When the forest emperor finally emerges, it is close to starving and attacks and devours any creature that comes within reach of its terrible, gnarled limbs.

entries.name: Continually Growing
entries: Forest emperors never stop growing, and specimens of gargantuan size have been found residing in the most desolate and treacherous forests and mountains, often in the lairs of dragons they have consumed. Unusually powerful forest emperors have even made it as far as the tangled roots of the World Tree itself, spending their time communing with evil fey spirits and the terrible serpents said to twine about its boughs.

trait.name: Falcon Dive
entries: If the falcon is flying and dives at least 20 feet straight toward a target, it has advantage on the next attack roll it makes against that target before the end of its turn. If the attack hits, it deals an extra 2 ({@damage 1d4}) damage to the target.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The falcon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

A forest falcon is a large, swift raptor adapted to agile flight through dense canopy rather than bursts of speed in open air. It prefers a high perch, watching for movement from prey on the forest floor. The falcon strikes in a diving ambush and can even run down prey on foot.

trait.name: Fragrant Aura
entries: The fragrant one emits a cloud of sweet-smelling pheromones within 20 feet of it. A giant, humanoid, or beast that starts its turn inside the aura must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature fails the saving throw three times in 1 hour, it is {@condition charmed} for 1 day and obeys the fragrant one's verbal or telepathic commands. If the creature suffers harm from the fragrant one or its allies or receives a suicidal command, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

The fragrant one can have no more than six creatures charmed at a time. The fragrant one can end its charm on a creature at any time (no action required). If the fragrant one has six creatures {@condition charmed} and a seventh creature fails its saving throw, the fragrant one can choose to release its charm on another creature to replace it with the new creature or to have the new creature unaffected by the aura.

trait.name: Strength in Numbers
entries: The fragrant one grows more powerful when it has {@condition charmed} allies. For each {@condition charmed} ally within 20 feet of it, the fragrant one gains 5 temporary hit points, its Armor Class increases by 1, and it deals an extra 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage when it hits with any attack. Temporary hp gained from this trait replenish every 1 minute.

action.name: Phrenic Antennae
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Interpose Ally
entries: When a creature the fragrant one can see targets it with an attack, the fragrant one can force a {@condition charmed} ally within 5 feet of it to move between it and the attack. The {@condition charmed} ally becomes the target of the attack instead. If the {@condition charmed} ally takes damage from this attack, it can immediately repeat the Fragrant Aura's saving throw, ending the {@condition charmed} condition on itself on a success.

A pale yellow and green slug-like creature with a benign expression on its round human face sits atop a large mushroom. Long antennae wave atop its bald head as its languid blue eyes observe its surroundings.

entries.name: Fairytale Fey
entries: A fragrant one is a whimsical and playful creature whose innocent and friendly demeanor hides a cunning intelligence. Fragrant ones feed on companionship and use their magical pheromones to inveigle themselves into the lives of other creatures, particularly woodland humanoids and giants. Strangely, a fragrant one knows nothing of real commitment or friendship, and all of its relationships are built on lies and deceptions.

entries.name: Safety in Numbers
entries: Fragrant ones are relatively weak when alone, barely having enough strength to fend off predators. When in the presence of multiple charmed companions, however, a fragrant one becomes much more of a threat, its body growing thick chitinous plates and its antennae lengthening.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The frost mole has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Snow Burrower
entries: The frost mole can burrow through nonmagical snow and ice in addition to sand, earth, and mud.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The frost mole has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Snow Pit
entries: If the frost mole moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature, it can dig a 5-foot-diameter, 20-foot-deep pit beneath the creature. If the target is Medium or smaller, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or fall into the pit and land {@condition prone}, taking falling damage as normal. If the target is Large or larger, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition restrained}. If the target is {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained}, the mole can make one claw attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) slashing damage.

Frost moles primarily eat meat and supplement their diets with plants that eke out an existence in arctic climates. Though they can overpower prey with their claws, they prefer to ensnare their victims in pits they dig as traps. Since frost moles build their warrens near farms where they can grab more docile livestock, their lairs present a nuisance to those who work the land during the short growing seasons. Creatures capable of taming frost moles find them extremely valuable. Frost mole masters train the moles to excavate treacherous pits around their lairs, protecting the masters from intruders.

trait.name: Aura of Lassitude
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the galidroo must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or feel lethargic until the start of its next turn. While lethargic, a creature can't use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can't make more than one melee or ranged attack on its turn. In addition, the creature can use either an action or a bonus action on its turn, but not both. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the galidroo's Aura of Lassitude for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Selective Precognition
entries: The galidroo can see into the past, present, and future simultaneously. It can innately cast {@spell divination} and {@spell legend lore} once per day each, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. The galidroo can't use these spells to gain information about itself or its personal future or past.

trait.name: Two-Headed
entries: The galidroo has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The galidroo makes four attacks: two with its bite and two with its claws. It can make one tail attack in place of its two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 10 ft. , one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the galidroo doesn't have another creature {@condition grappled}. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the galidroo can't use its tail on another target.

action.name: Prophetic Screech {@recharge 5}
entries: The galidroo unleashes a burst of prophetic power in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition incapacitated} for 1 minute as its mind is bombarded with visions of its past and future. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

This horrid creature is larger than an ox, and its hairless, wrinkled skin is covered in foul warts and pustules. The creature has two rat-like heads and a heavy tentacular tail that lashes the air malevolently.

entries.name: Wasteland Monstrosity
entries: The galidroo dwells primarily in desolate badlands, ravaged ruins, and areas where magic has corrupted the landscape and the creatures within it. Though powerful monsters in their own right, they are rarely at the top of the food chain and have to watch out for other monsters like {@creature purple worm|mm|purple worms} and {@creature ancient wasteland dragon|CCodex|wasteland dragons} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}).

entries.name: Prophetic Beasts
entries: The galidroo's two heads can see into the past, present, and future simultaneously, giving them a distorted, almost fatalistic view on life. Since the galidroo cannot see its own past or future, it is filled with endless frustration, and it zealously unleashes its rage upon anyone unfortunate enough to cross its path. Powerful liches frequently enslave galidroos, forcing the creatures to use their prophetic talents to serve the liches' plans. Because of the poor treatment they usually receive, galidroos are quick to turn on their "masters."

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The garlicle's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The garlicle has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks it makes in any terrain with ample obscuring plant life.

trait.name: Tearful Stench
entries: Each creature other than an {@creature alliumite|CCodex} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) or garlicle within 5 feet of the garlicle when it takes damage must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the start of the creature's next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the Tearful Stench of all {@creature alliumite|CCodex|alliumites} and garlicles for 1 minute.

action.name: Walking Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit ({@hit 6} to hit with {@spell shillelagh}), reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d6 - 2}) bludgeoning damage, 2 ({@damage 1d8 - 2}) bludgeoning damage if wielded with two hands, or 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage with {@spell shillelagh}.

action.name: Cloves of Fate {@recharge 4}
entries: The garlicle plucks cloves from its head and throws them at up to three creatures it can see within 30 feet of it. Roll a {@dice d4} for each creature. The garlicles allies have +1 on the roll while its enemies have a −1 on the roll. Determine the result and consult the following table.

colLabels: {@dice d4 + 1|d4 + 1|Cloves of Fate (Ally)} / {@dice d4 - 1|d4 - 1|Cloves of Fate (Enemies)}

rows.name: Worst Fortune
entries: Whatever the target is holding slips from its grasp into a random space within 5 feet of the target, and the target falls {@condition prone} as it trips over a rock, rain-dampened grass, its shoelaces, or similar.

rows.name: Bad Fortune
entries: The target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage and must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

rows.name: Adverse Fortune
entries: The target has disadvantage on its next attack roll.

rows.name: Favorable Fortune
entries: The target has advantage on its next attack roll.

rows.name: Good Fortune
entries: The target regains 5 ({@dice 2d4}) hp.

rows.name: Best Fortune
entries: The target's next successful hit is critical.

The leafy creature chants as it interprets a portent in a column of roiling, acrid smoke. The little creature shouts "Woe!" while pointing a gnarled finger, signaling the other leafy creatures to rise with readied weapons.

entries.name: Trusted Seers
entries: In the gardens of the {@creature alliumite|CCodex|alliumites} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}), alliumite elders practice divination magic to guide and protect their communities. Named "garlicles" by their communities, these elders use cloves plucked from their own heads to predict the future, casting the cloves like an augur's knucklebones. The residual fey magic that infuses all alliumites sometimes causes peculiar results in a garlicle's predictions.

entries.name: Wisdom Sought, Rarely Given
entries: Desperate folk often search for garlicles, seeking answers for such things as weather forecasts, lost relics, and hidden fates. These efforts are often in vain, as alliumites turn away most petitioners. Only those who earn the title "Gardenfriend" are allowed an audience. Often, the wrathful retaliate for being rejected, but the wise garlicles are quick to negotiate peace or, failing that, prepare an apt defense.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The gaunt one has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gaunt one makes two claw attacks. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}).

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Extract Heart
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one humanoid {@condition grappled} by the gaunt one. {@h}The target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If this damage reduces the target to 0 hp, the gaunt one kills the target by extracting and devouring its heart.
This corpse-like creature's flesh is gray, its body is emaciated, and its skin is pulled tight across its skeleton. A strange, writhing tentacle protrudes slightly from its gaping mouth.

entries.name: Unnatural Origin
entries: Centuries ago, an order of wizards, known as the Covenant of Infinum, found itself in need of slaves and descended upon a nearby human settlement. The order enslaved every villager and conducted magical experiments upon them in the wizards' remote mountain tower. The wizards were trying to create the perfect servitor race, using the villagers as a baser life form. The experiment failed spectacularly, unleashing a magical transformative wave upon the tower. Many of the wizards managed to escape, but all of the human slaves were caught in the magical chaos and were forever changed into gaunt ones.

entries.name: Undead Appearance
entries: At first glance, gaunt ones appear to be some form of undead creature, leading many to underestimate them. Their skin is pale, shrunken, and withered, and their teeth are yellow and jagged with receded gums.

entries.name: Hunger for Hearts
entries: Gaunt ones have an inherent hunger for hearts and often sit quietly for hours, listening for the heartbeats of nearby creatures. A gaunt one grabs hold of its prey and worms its tentacle-like tongue into the creature's mouth to extract the creature's heart. Insatiable, a gaunt one continues to eat the hearts of creatures it finds until there is nothing left to harvest. Lacking readily available food, it moves on.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The ghillie dubh has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forest terrain.

trait.name: One with the Trees
entries: If the ghillie dubh has spent at least 24 hours in a forest, it has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks while in that forest. In addition, it can spend 10 minutes focusing its attention on the forest and an invisible, sapling-shaped sensor anywhere in its forest within 1 mile of it. It can see and hear everything within 60 feet of this sensor, but it is {@condition deafened|phb|deaf} and {@condition blinded|phb|blind} with regard to its own senses while doing so. The sensor lasts for 1 minute or until the ghillie dubh dismisses it (no action required).

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The ghillie dubh can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Forest Knowledge {@recharge 6}
entries: The ghillie dubh can alter nearby creatures' knowledge of the forest, choosing one of the following. An effect lasts for 24 hours, until the creature leaves the ghillie dubh's forest, or until the ghillie dubh dismisses it as a bonus action.

items.name: Remove Knowledge
items.entry: Each creature within 30 feet of the ghillie dubh must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or become hopelessly lost in the ghillie dubh's forest. The creature has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks and takes 50 percent more time on overland travel, even delaying clearheaded companions.

items.name: Share Knowledge
items.entry: Each creature within 30 feet of the ghillie dubh has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks. The creature can move at a fast pace through forest terrain, and difficult terrain composed of nonmagical plants doesn't cost it extra movement.

entries: This bipedal creature seems to be a humanoid-shaped mound of leaves and moss given life. Dark pits in its head resemble empty eye sockets.

entries.name: Protectors of the Lost
entries: Ghillie dubhs hail from goodaligned arboreal planes. There, they guide visitors through the sometimes-confounding landscape. They often rescue those who incidentally succumb to the peaceful nature of planar woodlands and might otherwise perish. However, they find their services more useful on the Material Plane where nature is generally more unforgiving. Their desire to help mortals leads them to more extreme climates, with a strong preference for colder weather. Ghillie dubhs find lost travelers and guide these unfortunates to safe places. If a traveler impresses a ghillie dubh with knowledge or a desire for knowledge about the forest, the ghillie dubh gifts the traveler with some of its knowledge.

entries.name: Punishment of Transgression
entries: Likewise, a ghillie dubh expects visitors to the area it oversees to be respectful of the land. Ghillie dubhs lecture mild violators and briefly use nature to inconvenience them, such as by covering paths or removing tracks. More heinous acts—like wantonly slaughtering animals or setting trees ablaze—are met with physical retaliation.

entries.name: Part of the Forest
entries: Ghillie dubhs take on characteristics of the forests they call home to blend in seamlessly with the trees and other plants. They can listen to subtle variations in the trees' movements to receive early warning about attacks, and they can turn their attention to any part of the forest to ensure no harm is coming to an area.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The ghoul bat can't use its {@sense blindsight} while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The ghoul bat has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Undead Nature
entries: Ghoul bats don't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

This bat has an emaciated, three-foot-long torso and a head that looks like skin stretched over bone. Its jaws are unnaturally distended, and its mouth is full of needle-like teeth. Ghoul bats are popular messengers and pets among {@filter darakhul|bestiary|search=darakhul} and can be found both in colonies and alone throughout the Ghoul Imperium.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ghul's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: {@color *if using the {@i Midgard Heroes Handbook}, replace the indicated spells with {@i rolling thunder}, {@i spire of stone}, and {@i frozen razors}, respectively|777}

trait.name: Paralyzing Throes
entries: When the ghul dies, it explodes in a puff of noxious smoke. Each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The ghul has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

trait.name: Variable Immunity
entries: As a bonus action, the ghul changes one of its damage resistances to immunity to that type of damage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghul makes two attacks with its claws

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an elf or undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

A creature wearing a black turban steps out of the sudden fog. It is roughly the size and shape of a short man, with gray skin and pointed teeth. The thing sneers as it summons lightning to its hand, the air suddenly stinking of ozone. Its stony gray skin shifts to an icy blue as it raises its arm to direct its electrical attack.

entries.name: Elemental Remnants
entries: When an undead with the ability to raise more of their kind, such as a {@creature vampire}, {@creature wight}, or {@creature wraith}, slays a geniekin or other lesser elemental, the risen creature is a ghul instead. Rather than retaining control of whatever elemental forces it may have had during its life, the ghul becomes representative of all four of the classical elements.

entries.name: Unyielding Hunger
entries: Like more common {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls} and {@creature ghast|mm|ghasts}, a ghul's existence is focused around a relentless, agonizing need to consume living flesh. Ghuls favor live targets and can be seen sampling their meal even while battle rages around them. Despite their substantial innate magical ability, some ghuls prefer to rend with their claws, reveling in the tearing of flesh and the sensation of hot blood dripping from their cold bodies.

entries.name: Royal Aspirations
entries: Ghuls evolve over the centuries, gaining power and a semblance of their original personality, now twisted by countless evil acts. Their slow personal growth leads most ghuls to a craven existence, striking from the shadows and using their magic to flee if their prey puts up too much of a fight. If a ghul survives long enough, it gains enough power to be grudgingly acknowledged by lesser ghuls. These greater ghuls are often called "ghul kings" by those who encounter them, as the greater ghuls often create a semblance of a "royal court" out of lesser ghuls and other undead.

entries.name: Hungry Dead Nature
entries: The ghul doesn't require air or sleep.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tuck In
entries: The giant armadillo tucks its entire body into its shell, forming an armored ball. While in this form, it moves by rolling around, it has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and it can't take the {@action Attack} action or burrow. The giant armadillo can return to its true form as a bonus action.

Giant armadillos look like a hybrid of aardvark, {@creature rhinoceros}, and turtle with vicious-looking claws used primarily for burrowing. These creatures are generally placid and seek to avoid conflict whenever possible.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spray
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +4} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) fire damage.
Many types of beetles inhabit the world, and, depending on the location and culture, they are used as food, companions, or beasts of burden by its people.

entries.name: Forest Beetles
entries: Giant bombardier beetles lurk on the forest floor. A placid herbivore content to go about its business, the beetle has a powerful defense mechanism in the form of a boiling liquid it can spray to scald would-be predators as it makes its escape.

entries.name: Companions and Familiars
entries: Forest rangers often train bombardier beetles as companions, valuing the beetle's spray for its ability to deter beasts without setting fire to the forest.

trait.name: Intimidating Charge
entries: When a giant frilled lizard charges, it hisses ferociously, extends its neck frills, and darts forward on its hind legs, increasing its walking speed to 50 feet for that round. In addition, the creature charged must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for {@dice 1d6} rounds. The creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant frilled lizard makes one bite attack and one tail attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 4d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

These massive reptiles adore hot climates and often lie motionless while they sun themselves. When disturbed, giant frilled lizards become quite aggressive, hissing and protruding the large, jagged frill that surrounds their necks.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hp, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hp, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

Giant honey bees congregate in great swarms and fill hollows in rocky hillsides with their massive wax and honey hives. Far more intelligent than their diminutive cousins, giant honey bees sometimes enter into relationships with {@creature bearfolk|ToB} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}) or other creatures who can help protect the hive in exchange for a small share of the bees' honey. Unlike a normal honey bee, a giant honey bee who stings a creature doesn't lose its stinger.

Giant honey bees are rarely idle, often moving in elaborate, waggling dances of spirals and loops. This "dance" is actually a complex language the bees use to share staggeringly accurate directions and information about nearby threats and food sources with the rest of their hive.

entries.name: Bee Dance Language
entries: A character who has established peaceful contact with giant honey bees can learn Bee Dance as a language as outlined in the {@variantrule downtime activity: training|xge|downtime rules}.

While any character who learns it can understand {@language Bee Dance|ToB2}, a creature other than a giant honey bee can only convey basic concepts. A character who assumes the shape of a giant honey bee can communicate fully using the language

monster.name: Giant Husk
languages: understands all languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The husk can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Damage Transfer
entries: While it is grappling a creature, the husk takes only half the damage dealt to it, and all creatures {@condition grappled} by the husk take the other half split evenly.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The husk makes two attacks.

action.name: Smother
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Huge or smaller creature. {@h}The creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, {@condition blinded}, and at risk of suffocating. In addition, at the start of each of the target's turns, the target takes 14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. The husk can smother one Huge, two Large, or four Medium or smaller creatures at a time.
A grotesque human body moves like jelly. Its split-open front reveals the creature has no bones.
Husks are the opposite of {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons}: undead made entirely from tissue.

entries.name: Waste Not
entries: Powerful necromancers create husks from the leftovers of corpses used to animate skeletons. The creation of husks and skeletons at the same time allows a necromancer to create two undead with a single corpse.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A husk doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The leech can breathe air and water.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage, and the leech attaches to the target. While attached, the leech doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the leech's turns, the target loses 5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) hp due to blood loss. The leech can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 15 hp of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the leech.

Giant leeches lurk in placid ponds, babbling creeks, and mighty rivers. They slink through the dark forest waters with their distinctive vertical undulation, following any movement they sense toward fresh blood. Some varieties have adapted to life in the oceans, and a rare few dwell on land, though land-dwelling leeches prefer humid, moist climates.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The mongoose has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Defensive Roll
entries: The mongoose adds its {@skill Athletics} bonus to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the mongoose must see the attacker.

The giant mongoose slinks through the woods, searching out rodents and other small animals to prey upon. Like their smaller cousins, giant mongooses are notoriously resistant to venoms, and their distinctive "dance" in battle helps them avoid deadly strikes.

trait.name: Snowball Concealment
entries: The giant snow beetle has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks to hide if it is within 10 feet of a Large or larger snowball. It can attempt to hide even if another creature can see it clearly.

trait.name: Snowball Roll
entries: The giant snow beetle can spend 1 minute to roll up a ball of snow equal to its size.

action.name: Pincer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rotten Snowball Shove {@recharge 6}
entries: The giant snow beetle tosses one of its carrion-filled snowballs at a point it can see within 20 feet of it. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage and becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. On a success, a target takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}. A {@condition poisoned} creature can make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the poisoned condition on itself on a success.

action.name: Snowball Shove
entries: The giant snow beetle tosses one of its rolled snowballs at a point it can see within 20 feet of it. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a target takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.
Many types of beetles inhabit the world, and, depending on the location and culture, they are used as food, companions, or beasts of burden by its people.

entries.name: Arctic Beetles
entries: Giant snow beetles are carrion-eating beetles that inhabit the coldest parts of the world. They collect snow into large balls for use against their enemies, for protection for their lairs, and to house their eggs. When food is abundant, they pack extra carrion into snowballs, saving the food for later or for feeding freshly hatched larvae. When attacked, giant snow beetles fling any snowballs on-hand that don't contain their young, often splattering attackers with frozen, rotten meat.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The scorpion can hold its breath for 1 hour. If it is within 15 feet of the water's surface, it can use its tail as a breathing tube and doesn't need to hold its breath.

trait.name: Poison Injection
entries: When the scorpion hits with a proboscis attack against a {@condition grappled}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition restrained}, or {@condition stunned} creature, it deals an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The scorpion has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant water scorpion makes two claw attacks. If it is grappling a creature, it can use its proboscis once.

action.name: Proboscis
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target's Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature and the scorpion doesn't have another creature {@creature grappled}.

A common threat in canals, lagoons, bayous, and countless other bodies of water, the giant water scorpion is responsible for the deaths of many adventurers exploring waterways. Like most aquatic monsters, giant water scorpions are seldom at the top of the food chain in their native environment, and black dragons in particular enjoy snacking on them. Swamp and water-dwelling humanoids like lizardfolk have been known to use the giant water scorpion's carapace to create shields or coverings for their tents. The creature's long tail acts as a breathing tube for it, which is often harvested and used by intrepid explorers and inventors in the creation of diving bells and other apparatuses for traversing the stygian depths.

monster.name: Glacial Corrupter
languages: understands all languages it knew in life but can't speak

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +4} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Glacial Touch {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) cold. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage at the start of each of its turns, as a frozen shard lodges itself in the wound.  Any creature can take an action to remove the shard with a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check. The shard crumbles to snow if the target receives magical healing.
A humanoid slain by this attack rises in 1 week as a glacial corrupter, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed.
This skeleton's bones are crystal and caked with layers of frost and ice.

entries.name: Origin
entries: Glacial corrupters are similar in nature to most {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons}, except their bones have been transformed into crystal by the dark magic that created them. Cold has permeated their forms to such an extent that they exude an unnatural cold that cannot be warmed. They come about in one of two ways: when a creature is killed by a glacial corrupter or when a creature is killed by a {@creature sapphire jelly|ToB2}.

entries.name: Limited Intelligence
entries: Glacial corrupters are much like basic skeletons in that they are not truly self-aware. They are undead who either follow the simple instructions of necromancers or other creatures that can control them, or they follow a basic drive to destroy any living creatures they encounter. They are often used as guardians who do not tire, or as part of an attacking force for a greater power. They have no memories of their previous lives.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A glacial corrupter doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Ground Disruptor
entries: When the glacier behemoth moves, it can choose to make the area it moves through difficult terrain. When it uses Inexorable Charge, it automatically makes the ground difficult terrain.

trait.name: Unstoppable
entries: Difficult terrain composed of ice, rocks, sand, or natural vegetation, living or dead, doesn't cost the glacier behemoth extra movement. Its speed can't be reduced by any effect.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The glacier behemoth makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}33 ({@damage 4d12 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Inexorable Charge
entries: If the glacier behemoth moves at least 10 feet, it can then use this action to continue moving in a 40-foot line that is 15 feet wide. Each creature in this line must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}. The glacier behemoth's movement along this line doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}.
A depression in the ground trails in the wake of this six-legged creature. Aged ice, appearing more like granite, covers the creature's body.

entries.name: Slow but Steady
entries: Glacier behemoths earn their name from their resemblance to glaciers, including their slow, relentless pace. Their squat frames help conceal their six legs, reinforcing the notion that they are calved glaciers. Short of chasms blocking its way or the intervention of other glacier behemoths, nothing can stop a glacier behemoth when it moves. Its tough hide combined with its primal intellect render it fearless as it lumbers after its foes.

entries.name: Bulettekin
entries: Glacier behemoths are arctic relatives to bulettes, but their existence predates their temperate land–inhabiting kin. They are just as aggressive as their smaller cousins, but they don't have the speed or agility bulettes possess. They are also not as particular about the type of food they eat, owing to the lack of choice in the barren lands they inhabit.

entries.name: Path of Destruction
entries: Weighing at least 15 tons, a glacier behemoth can't help but crush everything in its wake. It leaves deep furrows in the ground as wide as its body. A sure sign of a wandering glacier behemoth is a crisscrossing set of ditches.

Despite its lack of stealth, a glacier behemoth can still take a settlement by surprise thanks to its ability to dig through the earth. The behemoth burrows into a building through the floor and attacks anything it finds. After this initial assault, it devastates the rest of the settlement, picking off those foolish enough to stay and fight.

trait.name: Fool's Gold
entries: If a creature steals one of the gorao-ka's money pouches, it loses {@dice 1d20} gp each time it finishes a long rest. A creature that steals more than one money pouch deducts an extra {@dice 1d20} gp for each additional stolen pouch. This effect ends when the thief freely gives double the amount of money it stole to another creature or organization.
A gorao-ka carries {@dice 1d10} pouches, each containing {@dice 1d20} gp. If the gorao-ka is killed, all the gold in its pouches turns into worthless stones after 1 minute.

trait.name: Silver Fountain
entries: When the gorao-ka is reduced to 0 hp, it explodes in a spray of silver pieces. Each creature within 5 feet of the gorao-ka that participated in killing it, such as by attacking it or casting a spell on it, must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage. The silver pieces disappear after 1 minute.

action.name: Sack of Coins
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Find a Penny {@recharge 5}
entries: The gorao-ka throws a copper piece into a space within 5 feet of it. A creature that is not hostile to the gorao-ka that picks up the copper piece is blessed with good luck. At any point within the next 1 hour, the creature can roll a {@dice d6} and add the number rolled to one attack roll, ability check, or saving throw.

Alternatively, the bearer of the coin can pass it to another creature of its choice. At any point within the next 8 hours, the new bearer of the coin can roll {@dice 2d6} and add the higher result to one attack roll, ability check, or saving throw.

The wizened, doll-sized woman sits beside a small shrine of bonsai branches. She smiles and reaches into a full pouch, removing a gold coin. She passes the coin with an encouraging nod to the desperate-looking man kneeling before her.

entries.name: Small Gods of Substance
entries: Gorao-ka represent small fortunes of both a physical and spiritual nature. Their shrines can be erected anywhere, but they are commonly found in settlements and widely-traveled areas. Larger settlements have multiple shrines, sometimes one or more per neighborhood, each of which is associated with a different gorao-ka.

entries.name: Gentle and Benevolent
entries: Gorao-ka have a kind look for every person that crosses their path. Each of them has a burning desire to assist people, and they grieve on the occasions that they can't. The laws governing their kind forbid them from extending aid to someone that hasn't made an offering at their shrine, though a gorao-ka accepts almost anything in tribute.

entries.name: Thieves' Bane
entries: Despite their generous natures, gorao-ka have no pity for those who steal from them. Fools who steal from gorao-ka swiftly discover their money inexplicably vanished, and can end up destitute if they don't make reparations.

entries.name: Immortal Spirit Nature
entries: The kami doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Kami in Midgard
entries: Kami are the small gods of the Winter Isles. Each kami is the spirit of something tangible, be it an ideal, an emotion, or a specific item or location. A kami can be summoned to the Material Plane by any creature that builds it a shrine and offers suitable tribute.
