Thin giants don't get along with most creatures, but they have been observed leading groups of {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls}, {@creature ettercap|mm|ettercaps}, and {@creature troll|mm|trolls} to capture and devour prey.

entries.name: Contortion Experts
entries: Thin giants have remarkable control over their bodies. They can twist their limbs into unnatural positions and even bend completely double. The flexibility and elasticity help the giants shrug off crushing blows. They can stay in contorted positions for extraordinary lengths of time and use this to their advantage to ambush unsuspecting creatures.

monster.name: Thornheart Guardian
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The thornheart guardian is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The thornheart guardian has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The thornheart guardian's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Woodland Walk
entries: Difficult terrain composed of nonmagical plants doesn't cost the thornheart guardian extra movement. In addition, the thornheart guardian can pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thornheart guardian makes three attacks: two with its barbed greatsword and one with its thorny whip

action.name: Barbed Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Thorny Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the guardian can automatically hit the target with its thorny whip, and the guardian can't make thorny whip attacks against other targets.

action.name: Grasp of the Briar {@recharge 5}
entries: The thornheart guardian summons grasping, thorny vines to impede and drain the life of its foes. The ground within 20 feet of the thornheart guardian becomes difficult terrain for 1 minute. This difficult terrain doesn't cost the thornheart guardian extra movement. A creature that enters or starts its turn in the area must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} by the plants. A {@condition restrained} creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature, including the {@condition  restrained} target, can take its action to break the target free of the vines by succeeding on a {@dc 16} Strength check.
A hulking figure clad in a black armor adorned with thorny ornaments slowly walks forward, seemingly unhindered by the thick vegetation of the surrounding woods.

Thornheart guardians are unyielding and merciless defenders of the forest domains of hags and other sinister fey. They are the twisted cousins of {@creature green knight of the woods|ccodex|green knights of the woods} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}), and good-aligned fey often send green knights on hunts to destroy thornheart guardians and their creators.

entries.name: Shadow Origins
entries: Thornheart guardians are created from the bodies and souls of unfortunate knights who foolishly fell for the charms of hags or dark fey and swore eternal servitude to them. In unholy ceremonies, hags fuse the knights' bodies with armor forged in the Shadow Realm then transform the knights' hearts into a cluster of enchanted thorns.

entries.name: Relentless and Loyal
entries: The thornheart guardian is a terror to behold. Once it has found its mark, it doesn't back down until the enemies of its sinister liege have been slain. Its enchanted heart gives it power over the plants around it, and it uses these plants to capture and kill its enemies.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: The thornheart guardian doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Lightning Absorption
entries: Whenever the thrummren is subjected to lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hp equal to the lightning damage dealt.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The thrummren has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons.
entries: The thrummren's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Storm Hide
entries: A creature that touches the thrummren or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage. The thrummren can choose for its rider to not be affected by this trait.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thrummren makes two attacks: one with its gore and one with its hooves.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d12 + 5}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) thunder damage.

action.name: Thunder Stomp {@recharge 5}
entries: The thrummren rears back and slams its front hooves into the ground. Each creature within 20 feet of the thrummren must make a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) thunder damage, is pushed up to 10 feet away from the thrummren, and is {@condition deafened} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't pushed or {@condition deafened}.

reaction.name: Protect Rider
entries: When the thrummren's rider is the target of an attack the thrummren can see, the thrummren can choose to become the target of the attack instead.
The massive, dog-faced elk charges into battle, lightning crackling between its hooves and antlers, as its giant rider throws bolts of lightning.
The sight of a storm giant charging to battle atop a baying thrummren is both breathtaking and terrifying.

entries.name: Heavenly Wanderers
entries: Herds of thrummrens migrate from mountain range to mountain range across vast regions of the Upper Planes. As they travel en masse, storm clouds gather above them, and the pounding of their hooves against the ground is akin to thunder. The lightning storms generated by their proximity are truly amazing to behold.

entries.name: Giant Bond
entries: Most thrummrens on the Material Plane serve as the mounts of storm giant cavaliers. The relationship between mount and rider is complex, with control of the pairing seeming to pass from one to the other and back. Thrummrens never abandon their riders, defending riders to the death if necessary. If its rider falls in battle, a thrummren continues its assault until all foes have fallen. The thrummren then returns the rider's body to its home community, regardless of the distance.

entries.name: Simurg Friends
entries: When they encounter each other on the forested mountainsides they prefer, thrummren and {@creature simurg|ccodex|simurgs} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creaure Codex.json}) share information. The two creatures often converse while on the move with the simurg perched atop the thrummren, looking to observers like some kind of chimeric creature with a long-feathered tail streaming behind it.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The tidehunter can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Net Maker
entries: With 1 minute of work, the tidehunter can create a net out of seaweed, rope, or similar material. The tidehunter typically carries 2 net.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage.
entries: The tidehunter has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tidehunter makes three attacks, only one of which can be with its net. It can use Reel in place of two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). The tidehunter has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}A Large or smaller creature hit by the net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. The net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger.  A creature can use its action to make a {@dc 15} Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 15 slashing damage to the net (AC 13) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

action.name: Reel
entries: The tidehunter pulls one creature restrained by its net up to 20 feet straight toward it. If the target is within 10 feet of the tidehunter at the end of this pull, the tidehunter can make one claw attack against it as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Entangle Weapon
entries: When the tidehunter is targeted by a melee weapon attack, the attacker must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw or miss the attack as the tidehunter uses its net to interfere with the weapon. The tidehunter must have an empty net to use this reaction.

Emerging from the surf, this massive crab-like beast has a hard, blue shell covered in barnacles. It holds a net of seaweed between its barbed claws, and a look of intelligence gleams in its elliptical, crimson eyes.

entries.name: Lurkers in the Shallows
entries: The tidehunter is an ambush hunter, using its coloration to surprise prey that venture into the shallows. Tidehunters are normally found along coasts with plentiful beaches and underwater vegetation, but some can be found in large lakes and river systems close to the open ocean. Most tidehunters are more than 20 feet across and are powerful enough to overcome a {@creature hunter shark} or small whale with ease. They have few natural predators, their intelligence and guile making them challenging prey.

entries.name: Net Weavers
entries: Tidehunters can weave nets out of kelp, seaweed, and other fibrous plant material with ease, constructing nets in a matter of minutes with the weirdly hooked barbs on their claws. Their nets are strong and can be thrown with great accuracy over a large distance. Indeed, even those on dry land are not immune to the tidehunter's attacks, and more than one human has been hauled into the surging tide from the apparent safety of the beach.

entries.name: Fishing Buddies
entries: While fisherfolk and tidehunters are normally at odds, a tidehunter will sometimes enter into an unspoken agreement with a group of fisherfolk, sharing the spoils of the sea while keeping out of each other's way.

monster.name: Timingila
languages: understands Abyssal, Celestial, Draconic, and Infernal but can't speak

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The timingila deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The timingila can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The timingila makes four attacks: one with its bite, one with its tail slap, and two with its flippers.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d10 + 9}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the timingila. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the timingila, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the timingila's turns.

If the timingila takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the timingila must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the timingila. If the timingila dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Flipper
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tail Slap
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away from the timingila and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Breach
entries: The timingila swims up to its swimming speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}. If it breaches the water's surface, it crashes back down, creating a wave in a 30-foot-wide, 120-foot-long line that is 30 feet tall. Any Gargantuan or smaller vehicles in the line are carried up to 100 feet away from the timingila and have a {@chance 50} chance of capsizing.

action.name: Resonating Roar {@recharge 5}
entries: The timingila roars in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 45 ({@damage 10d8}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition deafened}. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a vehicle is in the area, the roar travels into the vehicle and resonates inside it. Each creature inside the vehicle, even if the creature is outside the roar's area, must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take half the damage from the roar.
This massive shark-eel surges out of the water, opening titanic jaws large enough to bite a ship in half.

entries.name: Bribable
entries: Wise captains traveling through timingila hunting grounds often carry tithes and offerings in hopes of placating the creatures.

entries.name: Lesser Leviathan
entries: The timingila is one of the largest creatures in the seas. Some scholarly tomes suggest a connection between the timingila and rarer {@creature leviathan|mtf|leviathans} but no definitive proof has yet been found.

entries.name: Master of the Seas
entries: The timingila is an apex predator of the oceans. It hunts whales primarily but eats anything it can catch. The timingila is fiercely territorial and considers all of the ocean its personal domain.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Toad King's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The Toad King can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Anuran Passivism
entries: No frogs or toads can willingly attack the Toad King. They can be forced to do so through magical means.

trait.name: Feint
entries: As a bonus action before taking an action to attack, the Toad King can attempt to feint an opponent within 5 feet of him. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw, or the Toad King has advantage on his next attack.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Toad King has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The Toad King's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If he dies, the Toad King's soul reforms on the Astral Plane. In {@dice 1d6} days, it inhabits the body of another frog or toad on the Material Plane, which then becomes the Toad King (with all of the hp and abilities thereof). Only killing every frog and toad on the Material Plane will prevent this trait from functioning.

trait.name: Royal Croak
entries: As a bonus action, the Toad King croaks at a frog or toad within 30 feet of him. If the target can hear him, it can make one weapon attack as a reaction against any creature that has attacked the Toad King since the end of his previous turn.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The Toad King can use his action to polymorph into a Large emerald frog, a Medium male human, or back into his true Medium bipedal toad form. His statistics, other than his size, are the same in each form—with the exception that only his true and frog forms retain his swimming speed. Any equipment he is wearing or carrying transforms with him. He reverts to his true form if he dies.

trait.name: Speak with Frogs and Toads
entries: The Toad King can communicate with frogs and toads as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The Toad King's long jump is up to 20 feet and his high jump is up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: In frog form, the Toad King makes two bite attacks. In humanoid form, he makes three rapier attacks. In his true form, he makes three attacks: one with his bite and two with his rapier.

action.name: Bite (Frog Form and True Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the Toad King can automatically hit the target with his bite, and he can't make bite attacks against other targets. When the Toad King moves, any Medium or smaller target he is grappling moves with him.

action.name: Rapier (Human and True Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry (Human and True Form Only)
entries: The Toad King adds 4 to his AC against one melee attack that would hit him. To do so, the Toad King must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.
This human-sized toad has an enormous head and expressive onyx eyes. His broad smile, accentuated by wrinkles and warts, complements his regal bearing and attire.

entries.name: King of Frogs
entries: All amphibians respect the Toad King, but frogs and toads follow his orders. He lives among them in swampy areas and often adds his voice to their croaking choruses.

entries.name: Fairy-tale Nobility
entries: Comporting himself with dignity, the Toad King enjoys pretending to be a prince or king cursed to take a toad's form. He spins a grand tale about witches or fey enchanters and convinces listeners to undertake elaborate quests to break the curse. He is generous with castings of {@spell heroism} to aid those who agree to do his bidding, but he often insists on casting {@spell geas} to ensure compliance. The Toad King hints at rewards but tries not to promise anything specific. If he does guarantee a reward, he is obligated to make good on his promise if his pawns succeed.

entries.name: On the Cusp of Legend
entries: The Toad King has not quite achieved status equivalent to other animal lords. However, he expects he will undergo apotheosis when he convinces a hero or group of heroes to complete a grand adventure on his behalf.

entries.name: The Toad King's Quests
entries: The Toad King enjoys sending adventurers on elaborate quests to cure his "curse," often spinning tales of his woeful plight wrought at the hands of evil fey or witches. Here are some example quests for particularly helpful adventurers:

items: Retrieve the warty nose of a {@creature green hag} who lives deep in the swamp, then burn it in the remains of a {@creature yowler|ToB2}. The Toad King must inhale the rotten perfume.
Collect a dozen thornless roses from the cursed forest and sprinkle the petals in an ellipse around the Toad King at midnight on the night of a full moon.
Bathe a false gemstone from an {@creature arachnocrat|ToB2} in the molten saliva of a {@creature hoard drake|ToB2}, then place the glistening jewel on the Toad King's forehead.
Obtain a gallon of water once inhabited by a {@creature crinaea|ToB2}. The water must be freely given and free of poison, and the Toad King must bathe in it for 24 hours.
Soak the feather of a {@creature lymarien|ToB2} in the tears of {@creature guardian naga}. The Toad King must consume the tear-soaked feather before the next crescent moon.

Bring the Toad King a cloak of {@creature winter wolf} fur held together by a clasp made from a {@creature haleshi|ToB2|haleshi's} clam. The clam must have been used by the {@creature haleshi|ToB2} at least once to magically transport itself and others.

The Toad King must consume a potion made of {@creature basilisk} eyes, {@creature pixie} dust, and {@item holy water (flask)|phb|holy water}. The potion must be frozen by an {@creature ice bogie|ToB2} before consumption.
Weave a crown made of hair from a {@creature sea hag}, an {@creature orphan of the black|ToB2}, and a {@creature mountain nymph|ToB2}, then place the crown on the Toad King's head.

Coat an acorn in a paste made from ashes left in an {@creature ashen custodian|ToB2|ashen custodian's} wake and plant it in the soil of the Toad King's home. The first seed the tree bears will cure the Toad King.

entries.name: Animal Lords
entries: While humanoids have vast pantheons and divine figures of every stripe, the animals of the world have much simpler forms of faith. Among each species there is always one paragon that embodies the animal spirit in a humanoid form, the better to speak to others and represent the animals in celestial councils.

The {@filter animal lords|bestiary|search=Animal Lord} first appear in the {@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}. Two additional animal lords are presented here: the Queen of Scorpions, an exiled animal lord who manipulates the mortal world through a complex network of thieves and spies from her desert home, and the Toad King, a burgeoning animal lord who seeks apotheosis by sending brave heroes on complex quests.

trait.name: Aura of Pain
entries: At the start of each of the qiqirn's turns, each creature within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage and must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on its next melee attack roll.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The qiqirn has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Self-loathing
entries: A creature the qiqirn can hear can use its action to say "qiqirn" and make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check. If it does so, the qiqirn must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to the creature's Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check or be {@condition frightened} of that creature until the end of its next turn. If the qiqirn succeeds on the saving throw, it can't be {@condition frightened} by that creature for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tormented qiqirn makes two bite attacks. Alternatively, it can use Spiteful Howl twice.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Spiteful Howl
entries: The qiqirn releases a spiteful howl at one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can hear the qiqirn, it must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Unnerving Whispers {@recharge 5}
entries: The qiqirn whispers the last words of the spirits infusing it into the minds of up to three creatures it can see within 60 feet of it. Each creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage and suffer a random effect for 1 minute. Roll a {@dice d6} to determine the effect: {@condition unconscious} (1), {@condition deafened} (2), {@condition incapacitated} (3), {@condition stunned} (4), {@condition frightened} (5), {@condition paralyzed} (6). A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Protective Spirits
entries: When the qiqirn takes damage, the spirits infusing it rise up to protect it. Roll {@dice 2d8} and reduce the damage by the result.
This strange dog is hairless except for the thick, dark fur that runs along its bony, ridged back.

entries.name: Arctic Legends
entries: Oral histories of the north are rich with tales of the qiqirn. The tales say they are drawn to mankind's warm hearths and homes and that the sounds of music and mirth enrage them. The stories note that qiqirn are jealous of dogs and that jealousy leads them to kill canines whenever they can. More than a few tales are told of qiqirn that have foolishly become trapped while trying to get at a settlement's sled dogs. Most importantly, northern children are told that a qiqirn can be driven off by shouting its name at it.

entries.name: Afraid of Civilization
entries: Feared as they are by northern communities, qiqirn fear those people in turn. When threatened by civilized folk, qiqirn are quick to flee. When this occurs, a qiqirn often returns by night to steal the food or livestock it was previously denied. When qiqirn attacks have driven an entire community to hunt it, the monster leaves the region for easier hunting grounds.

entries.name: Spirit Dog
entries: A qiqirn's fear of civilization is built on the basis of self-preservation. The qiqirn is an unwilling conduit for souls of the damned that aren't strong enough to travel to the afterlife. These spirits steadily torment the qiqirn, causing it pain and infusing it with necrotic power as they seek their own respite. As the {@creature qiqirn|ToB2} spends more time around civilization, it accrues more damned souls. Much as a fiend transforms to higher forms as it devours souls, a qiqirn that lives long enough or spends enough time around civilization undergoes a painful transformation from its constant contact with the growing number of tormented souls. These qiqirn seek to destroy all they encounter, sharing their pain with others. Scholars speculate the power of the spirits would eventually kill the tormented qiqirn if the creature lost the ability to offload the pain coursing from the other side of the veil.

entries.name: Curing a Qiqirn
entries: {@creature Qiqirn|ToB2} live in remote arctic regions to avoid excessive contact with humanoids, but they can't resist warm hearths and the easy prey in livestock pens. No matter how much a qiqirn tries to avoid civilization, eventually it accrues enough souls and becomes a tormented qiqirn. Though qiqirn can never be freed of the quirk that draws damned souls to them, they can be freed of the souls burdening them by putting those souls to rest. Ankou, in particular, are adept at releasing the qiqirn of its burden of souls, and {@creature ankou soul herald|ccodex|ankou soul heralds} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) often assign {@creature ankou soul seeker|ccodex|soul seekers} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) to areas inhabited by qiqirn to ensure the souls get the proper respite and that the qiqirn doesn't become tormented.

A {@creature tormented qiqirn|ToB2} can be freed of its burden of souls only by an {@creature ankou soul herald|ccodex} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) or a {@spell wish} spell. If freed of its burden, a tormented qiqirn shrinks back into its standard form.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lunarchidna is a 8th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). The lunarchidna has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Light Invisibility
entries: The lunarchidna is {@condition invisible} while in bright or dim light.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The lunarchidna can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the lunarchidna has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The lunarchidna ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lunarchidna makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) necrotic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or its hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +6} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by webbing. As an action the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 13} Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

action.name: Lunar Beam {@recharge 5}
entries: The lunarchidna flashes a beam of moonlight in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A four-armed, four-legged creature in the vague shape of a human—but seemingly made of fine spider silk—moves down a tree, slowly chanting the incantation of a spell in the pale light of the full moon.

entries.name: Made in Corrupt Forests
entries: Lunarchidnas are beings of moonlight and spider silk created in forests permeated by residual dark magic. When this magic coalesces on a spider web touched by the light of a full moon, the web animates. The web gains life and flies through the forest, gathering other webs until it collects enough silk to form a faceless, humanoid body, with four legs and four arms.

entries.name: Hatred of Elves
entries: Lunarchidnas hate elves and love to make the creatures suffer. They poison water sources, set fire to villages, and bait monsters into stampeding through elf communities. These aberrations especially enjoy stealing away elf children to use as bait to trap the adults that come to the rescue.

entries.name: Cyclical Power
entries: The lunarchidna's power is tied to the moon. When the skies are dark during a new moon, the lunarchidna becomes more shadow than living web. Its mental ability dulls, and it becomes barely more than a savage animal. When a full moon brightens the night, however, the lunarchidna becomes a conduit of lunar light and can channel that power through its body. Using its heightened intellect, it makes plans, writes notes, and plots from the safety of the trees where it makes its home. In the intermittent phases of the moon, the lunarchidna is a more than capable hunter, trapping and devouring prey it encounters while retaining enough knowledge of its plans and magic to further its goals in minor ways. The lunarchidna's statistics change cyclically as shown on the Lunarchidna Moon Phase table.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

trait.name: False Appearance (Tree Form Only)
entries: While the skinner remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal tree.

trait.name: Inhabit Tree
entries: As a bonus action, the skinner touches a Medium or larger tree that is not a creature and disappears inside it. While inside the tree, the skinner has {@sense tremorsense|MM} with a radius of 30 feet, has an AC of 15, has a speed of 0, and has vulnerability to fire damage. When the skinner is reduced to 15 hp, the tree dies and the skinner appears within 5 feet of the dead tree or in the nearest unoccupied space. The skinner can exit the tree as a bonus action, appearing within 5 feet of the tree in the nearest unoccupied space, and the tree reverts to being an object. The skinner can inhabit a tree for only 3 days at most before the tree dies, requiring the skinner to seek another vessel.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The skinner has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Vine Whip (Tree Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and if the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}). The skinner can grapple up to two creatures at one time.

action.name: Squeeze (Tree Form Only)
entries: The tree skinner makes one vine whip attack against a creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is also unable to breathe or cast spells with verbal components until this grapple ends.
A feminine creature made of decaying, thorny plant life gives a wicked laugh as she touches a tree and disappears. Moments later, the tree emits the same laugh as it swings its branches.

entries.name: Formed by Hags
entries: {@creature night hag|mm|Night hags} create tree skinners by taking advantage of {@creature dryad|mm|dryads} that have been driven mad by the death of their trees. The hags promise the dryads a chance to connect with trees again and induce them into submitting to a special ritual. The ritual used to transform a dryad into a skinner also instills in the dryad a hatred of all fey. The irony of a former dryad using trees to murder fey creatures delights the hags to no end.

entries.name: Tree Puppeteers
entries: Tree skinners can inhabit trees, turning the plants into weapons that can destroy forest communities. The evil essence of a skinner slowly rots a tree from the inside out, eventually killing the plant. When the tree dies, the skinner is expelled and becomes agitated until she finds a new tree to inhabit.

entries.name: Skinner Bands
entries: Tree skinners all share the same desire—the destruction of all fey creatures. When the skinners encounter others of their kind, they join forces to attack communities of fey. As long as they have fey to attack, the group will stay together indefinitely, otherwise the lack of a common enemy causes infighting, leading to the dissolution of the group.

entries.name: Hated by Treants
entries: {@creature treant|mm|Treants} abhor tree skinners, seeing them as abominations that manipulate plants and sap the life of trees. If a treant hears of skinner activity, it stops at nothing to slay the fiend.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The tricenatorus has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hp.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the tricenatorus takes 40 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hp, it is reduced to 1 hp instead.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The tricenatorus deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Tail Spike Regrowth
entries: The tricenatorus has twenty-four tail spikes. Used spikes regrow when the tricenatorus finishes a long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tricenatorus makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its gore, or two with its tail spikes. It can't use its gore against a creature {@condition restrained} by its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}34 ({@damage 4d12 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the tricenatorus can't bite another target.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail Spike
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +12} to hit, range 150/300 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) piercing damage.
A bipedal dinosaur with massive horns on its face, back, and tail roars, revealing an enormous mouth filled with rows of razor teeth.
Tricenatoruses are the rage-filled result of a transmutation experiment gone wrong.

entries.name: Unnatural Mistakes
entries: A transmutation wizard attempted to magically bring together two dinosaurs to create the ultimate guardian, one with the power of the {@creature tyrannosaurus rex|mm|tyrannosaurus} and the docile nature of the {@creature triceratops}. Instead, the wizard created unnatural, spiked monsters with a hunger for flesh and an unmatched rage.

entries.name: Always Angry
entries: From the moment they hatch, tricenatoruses are angry. This rage makes them reckless and difficult to harm. Most of these monstrous dinosaurs stay deep within the jungle, but tricenatoruses are relentless when they find prey, leading them to sometimes chase explorers into civilized settlements.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The trollkin regains 1 hp at the start of its turn. If the trollkin takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the trollkin's next turn. The trollkin dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hp and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Thick Hide
entries: The trollkin's skin is thick and tough, granting it a +1 bonus to Armor Class. This bonus is included in the trollkin's AC.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The trollkin makes two spear attacks or one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.
Screams echo in the night as spears meet wood and flesh. One trollkin pulls its spear from its latest victim while its companion raids the victim's larder.

Trollkin raiders are greedy and efficient, moving together under the command of a trollkin leader to take apart a village, a caravan, or a small fortress. Their goal is generally food and portable wealth. Their training as a unit is not extensive but raiders know, trust, and fight for one another.

entries.name: Night Attacks
entries: Trollkin raiders attack in a fast-moving, nocturnal group, often using a group of panicked animals or a fire as a distraction in one place while they attack elsewhere. Their assaults are never daylight attacks over open ground; they much prefer surprise and the confusion of night attacks.

entries.name: Mounted or River Routes
entries: While trollkin raiders can lope for miles across taiga or through forests, they far prefer to ride horses or row up a river. It gives them both speed and the ability to carry more plunder.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the tzepharion's {@sense darkvision}.

trait.name: Eye of Rage
entries: As a bonus action, the tzepharion incites rage in up to three beasts or monstrosities it can see within 60 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become enraged until the end of its next turn. While enraged, it has advantage on its attack rolls, but it is unable to distinguish friend from foe and must attack the nearest creature other than the tzepharion. This trait doesn't work on targets with an Intelligence of 6 or higher.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The tzepharion has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The tzepharion has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the devil's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tzepharion devil makes one bite attack and four claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Soul Jolt {@recharge 6}
entries: The tzepharion leaps up to 20 feet through the air and makes a claw attack against a target within reach. If it hits, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or its soul is forced out of its body, appearing 20 feet in a random direction away from its body, for 1 minute. The creature has control of its soul, which is {@condition invisible} and can move through creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain, but it can't cast spells or take any actions. The creature's body is knocked {@condition unconscious} and can't be awoken until its soul returns, but it can take damage as normal. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, reoccupying its body on a success. Alternatively, a creature can reoccupy its body early if it starts its turn within 5 feet of its body. If a creature doesn't return to its body within 1 minute, the creature dies. If its body is reduced to 0 hp before the creature reoccupies its body, the creature dies.

Strutting forward on four legs tipped with sharp talons, this raptor-like fiend has dark crimson feathers covering its scaled hide and an extended, eyeless, saw-toothed maw. A baleful orange eye glares from the monster's chest.

entries.name: Primeval Devils
entries: Tzepharions are perhaps the most savage and primal of all devils. They care little for the schemes and temptations of other devils and are happy to spend their time chasing and devouring lower life forms. For this reason, tzepharions are treated as simple beasts by other fiends, and packs of tzepharions are sometimes employed by pit fiends and arch-devils on hunting trips.

entries.name: Structured Packs
entries: Despite their limited intelligence, tzepharions are highly lawful fiends and organize themselves into tightly regimented packs to hunt down prey. Each tzepharion knows its place in the pack and coordinates with its fellows in battle. Tzepharions on the Material Plane band together for survival or work to control a pack of {@creature dire wolf|mm|dire wolves}, a pride of {@creature lion|mm|lions}, or another group of carnivorous beasts.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The ulnorya is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Photoadaptive Hide
entries: If the ulnorya didn't move on its previous turn, it is {@condition invisible}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ulnorya makes four attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and two with its tentacles.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hp, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hp, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Replicate (1/Day)
entries: The ulnorya separates itself into two identical copies for up to 1 hour. The new ulnoryas' hp totals are equal to the original ulnorya's hp total divided by 2 (rounded down), and each is affected by any conditions, spells, and other magical effects that affected the original ulnorya. The new ulnoryas otherwise retain the same statistics as the original, except neither has this action. The new ulnoryas act on the same initiative count as the original ulnorya and occupy any unoccupied spaces within 5 feet of the original ulnorya's space.

If one ulnorya starts its turn within 5 feet of its other half, they can each use their reactions to recombine. The recombined ulnorya's hp total is equal to the combined hp total of the two ulnoryas, and it is affected by any conditions, spells, and other magical effects currently affecting either of the combining ulnoryas. The ulnorya automatically recombines if both of its halves are still alive at the end of the hour. If only one ulnorya remains alive at the end of the hour, it gains this action after it finishes a long rest.
Eight long, writhing tentacles support and propel this snarling horror's oblong body while its jagged maw reveals rows of razor teeth.

entries.name: Invisible Hunter
entries: The ulnorya lives to hunt, using its natural invisibility to surprise prey or swiftly chase down its next meal. Replicating itself allows the ulnorya to be its own hunting partner, and it uses this to stage ambushes or surround its victims.

entries.name: Magical Oddity
entries: Whether it was created by a mad druid or some arcane guild's ill-advised experimentation, the ulnorya combines elements of spiders, scorpions, and octopuses. Asexual as a species, ulnorya create new offspring by implanting an egg within corpses slain by the ulnorya's poison. Within five days, the egg hatches into a new ulnorya.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The uridimmu's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}). The uridimmu can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Chaos Mace
entries: The uridimmu's attacks with its mace are magical. When the uridimmu hits with its mace, the mace deals an extra {@dice 4d8} fire, lightning, or radiant damage (included in the attack). The uridimmu chooses the type of damage when making the attack.

trait.name: Heroic Aura
entries: Each friendly creature within 20 feet of the uridimmu can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}. In addition, when a friendly creature within 20 feet of the uridimmu makes an attack roll or a saving throw, it can roll a {@dice d4} and add the result to the attack roll or saving throw. The uridimmu's aura doesn't work in the area of an {@spell antimagic field} spell or while in a temple, shrine, or other structure dedicated to a chaotic deity.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The uridimmu has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uridimmu makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its mace.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Mace
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire, lightning, or radiant damage.

action.name: Heavenly Roar {@recharge 5}
entries: The uridimmu can unleash a powerful roar imbued with divine power in a 30-foot cone. A target caught within this cone must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Fiends have disadvantage on this saving throw.

This tall, muscular humanoid has bronze skin and the wings of a hawk. Its head is that of a majestic hunting hound with the teeth and reddish-gold mane of a lion, and it holds a flaming mace in its hands.

entries.name: Bastard Sons of Chaos
entries: The first uridimmus were the illegitimate offspring of a demon lord and an unknown entity of chaos and were soundly defeated by a powerful deity of law. After their defeat, the uridimmus chose to serve the god as guardians of the heavenly realm. The tainted origin of uridimmus manifests in the chaotic mass of fire, lightning, and radiance that clings to the heads of their maces.

entries.name: Tainted Servants of Law
entries: Uridimmus are tireless guardians, and most are tasked with guarding the portals into the lawful planes. Some also serve the deities directly as bodyguards or lead groups of lesser celestials in battle. While uridimmus are unwavering and steadfast guardians, they are also completely merciless in combat and not above making examples out of trespassers. This tendency sometimes causes friction between the uridimmu and other angels, like {@creature planetar|mm|planetars}, who claim that the souls of uridimmus are still tainted with evil.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: An uridimmu doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Prehensile Tendrils
entries: The valkruung has 10 shiny blue-gray tendrils that constantly grab at things in the environment. Each tendril can pick up or hold a Tiny object, such as a coin or piece of jewelry, that isn't being worn or carried. If it uses all 10 of its tendrils, the valkruung can carry a single Small object, such as a {@item backpack|phb}. The valkruung can use its tendrils to interact with objects, but it can't use them to wield a weapon. It has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks when using its tendrils and can use its tendrils to disarm opponents (see the Disarming Tendrils reaction).

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target suffers an itchy rash, and, at the start of each of its turns, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving or spend its action furiously scratching the rash. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Disarming Tendrils
entries: When a creature the valkruung can see targets it with a melee weapon attack, the attacker must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or its weapon is knocked out of its grasp into a random unoccupied space within 5 feet of the attacker. The valkruung can't use this reaction against attackers wielding a heavy or two-handed weapon.
Standing only a few feet tall, this odd simian creature has charcoal-colored skin and glowing eyes. Thin, blue-gray tendrils cover almost every inch of its body, and it smells faintly of burnt honey.

entries.name: Incorrigible Kleptomaniacs
entries: Few creatures cause as much annoyance to shopkeepers, merchants, and farmers as the valkruung, a tiny monkey-like creature covered in grasping tendrils that lurks atop roofs and clambers through trees, looking for food and objects to steal. Attracted to anything that glitters, jangles, or just plain smells nice, the valkruung steals anything regardless of its actual worth. Valkruungs snatch purses from unsuspecting passersby and fruit and bread from vendors to take back to their lairs. They steal objects they don't need and refuse to return them, running off while snickering wildly.

entries.name: Shrines of Riches
entries: Anything a valkruung steals and doesn't eat is placed in a central location in its nest, often around an existing statue, altar, or other large object. Eventually, this object becomes covered in a variety of clutter, some of which may be valuable. A valkruung treats all of its objects equally and attacks anyone who tries to take something from the pile.

entries.name: Den of Thieves
entries: Valkruungs are social creatures and live in groups of ten to twenty. The job of child-rearing is shared by all members of the group equally, and young valkruungs spend the first parts of their lives carried around on various adults' backs, where the adults' tendrils keep them safe. Valkruungs are more intelligent than they appear and have a rudimentary grasp of language, typically insults that have been hurled their way.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The vallowex can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aura of Thirst
entries: At the start of each of the vallowex's turns, each creature within 30 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on its next attack roll or ability check as a gnawing thirst distracts it. For each minute a creature stays in the vallowex's aura, it gains one level of {@condition exhaustion} from dehydration. A level of {@condition exhaustion} is removed if the creature uses an action to drink 1 pint of water. A vallowex is immune to its own Aura of Thirst as well as the auras of other vallowexes.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The vallowex has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vallowex makes two attacks: one with its spiked tongue and one with its tail.

action.name: Spiked Tongue
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the vallowex can't use its spiked tongue against another target.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The vallowex makes one spiked tongue attack against a Medium or smaller target it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is also swallowed, and the grapple ends. The swallowed target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the vallowex, and it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the vallowex's turns. The vallowex can have only one creature swallowed at a time. If the vallowex takes 15 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the vallowex must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate the creature, which falls {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet of the vallowex. If the vallowex dies, the swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 10 feet of movement, exiting prone.

action.name: Release Eggs (1/Week)
entries: A vallowex can release a 40-foot-radius cloud of microscopic eggs into a body of water it touches. The eggs live for 1 hour. Any humanoid or beast that drinks the eggs must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be infected with a disease—a vallowex tadpole. A host can carry only one vallowex tadpole to term at a time. While diseased, the host must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the end of each long rest. On a failed save, the host's Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. This reduction lasts until the host finishes a long rest after the disease is cured. If the host's Strength score is reduced to 0, the host dies, and a vallowex emerges from the corpse. If the host succeeds on three saving throws or the disease is magically cured, the unborn tadpole disintegrates.
A creature with two legs and a flat tail emerges from the water. Its wide mouth opens, revealing a spiked tongue.

entries.name: Luring with Thirst
entries: The vallowex haunts woodland rivers, luring in prey with its thirst-inducing aura. When a creature stops to drink, the vallowex attacks and drags the creature into the water to feast.

entries.name: Reproduce through Hosts
entries: Vallowexes release eggs into potable water. After a creature drinks the eggs, a tadpole hatches in its stomach. The tadpole slowly consumes the host from the inside out, emerging as a vallowex when the host dies.

trait.name: Constant Racket
entries: The vangsluagh has disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

trait.name: Distracting Cacophony
entries: The vangsluagh constantly emits a din of bleats, trills, and trumpets. A creature that casts a spell while it is within 30 feet of the vangsluagh must make a {@dc 13} Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw. (The type of saving throw required is dependent on the spellcasting creature's spellcasting ability score.) On a failed save, the spell isn't cast, and the spell slot isn't expended. In addition, a creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the vangsluagh and is maintaining concentration on a spell must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or it loses concentration on the spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vangsluagh makes two tentacle lash attacks.

action.name: Tentacle Lash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Sonic Bullet
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit +5} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) thunder damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Agonizing Trill (Recharge After a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The vangsluagh increases the pitch of its cacophony to deadly levels. Each creature within 30 feet of the vangsluagh must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) thunder damage and is {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition stunned}. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
A writhing mass of hundreds of rubbery, blue-grey tentacles rises from a human sized pair of legs ending in elephantine feet. Each tentacle ends in an eerily human-looking mouth.

entries.name: Damned Pipers
entries: Vangsluagh create a din everywhere they go; the mouths on their tentacles perpetually scream, whistle, bleat, growl, and cry. Even in instances where a vangsluagh may want a quiet entrance or stealthy ambush, their own bodies betray them. Stories have emerged from their magic-blasted homeland of vangsluagh that are capable of silencing the noise surrounding them.

entries.name: Defilers of Beauty
entries: Vangsluagh despise pretty things, be they creature, object, or structure. Given the opportunity, a vangsluagh prefers spending its time smashing beautiful things to bits. The absence of beauty doesn't always calm these creatures, however. They target living creatures as a priority in such occurrences.

entries.name: Vangsluagh in Midgard
entries: Creatures maddened in the shadow of Uthul Vangslagish eventually transform into vangsluagh, the doom singing, wandering heralds of their dread parent. Vangsluagh wander the lands of the Wasted West, spreading discord whenever they come into contact with mortals. Some sages contend that Uthul-Vangslagish will call all of its children home when it is time to end the world with its song.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The linnorm can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Blood Scent
entries: The linnorm can smell blood in the water within 5 miles of it. It can determine whether the blood is fresh or old and what type of creature shed the blood. In addition, the linnorm has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to find or track a creature that doesn't have all its hp.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The linnorm can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the linnorm doesn't have two other creatures {@condition grappled}. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the linnorm's choice that is within 120 feet of the linnorm and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the linnorm's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Inky Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The linnorm exhales a cloud of briny ink in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 52 ({@damage 15d6}) necrotic damage and is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition blinded}. A {@condition blinded} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
The immense reptile soars through the water, long and sleek. Its powerful tail undulates rhythmically, threatening all in its terrifying wake.

entries.name: Terrors of the Deep
entries: Vent linnorms live near hydrothermal fissures located in the deepest parts of the ocean. When they are not hunting, they can be found basking in their lairs, enjoying the dark, warm waters of their homes. They are proficient hunters whose diet includes all varieties of sharks and whales, giant squid, {@creature dragon turtle|mm|dragon turtles}, {@creature dragon eel|ToB|dragon eels} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}), and {@creature young sea dragon|ToB|younger sea dragons} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}). While they are generally solitary creatures, mated pairs sometimes team up to hunt ancient sea dragons and kraken before resuming their solitary lives.

entries.name: Primeval Dragons
entries: Like their draconic kin, vent linnorms enjoy amassing hoards of treasure and burying it in the silty floor of their lairs. Young linnorms spend much of their time searching through the wreckage of sunken vessels, while older ones actively sink passing ships, eating the sailors and picking up the fallen treasures at their leisure.

entries.name: Aboleth Hunters
entries: Through cleverness and scheming, {@creature aboleth|mm|aboleths} often dominate vent linnorms for use as servants and war beasts, and enjoy doing so. For their part, linnorms despise aboleths for enslaving them. A vent linnorm who becomes aware of the presence of aboleths immediately ceases its current activity and moves to destroy its hated enemy.

monster.name: Veteran Swordbreaker Skeleton
languages: understands all languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Fossilized Bones
entries: Any nonmagical slashing or piercing weapon made of metal or wood that hits the swordbreaker skeleton cracks. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal or wood that hits the swordbreaker skeleton is destroyed after dealing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The veteran swordbreaker skeleton makes two longsword attacks. If it has a shortsword drawn, it can also make a shortsword attack.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +3} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) piercing damage.
Tougher than a typical animated skeleton, these undead are raised from skeletal remains that have fossilized.

entries.name: Bones of Stone
entries: The swordbreaker skeleton's bones have fossilized and become stony. Most weapons shatter against these bones, but the fossilization makes the skeletons more susceptible to magic that harms stone or that causes concussive bursts of sound.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A swordbreaker skeleton doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Swordbreaker Skeleton Template
entries: Any creature that has been dead for more than 100 years and that has a skeletal structure can be animated as a swordbreaker skeleton. When a creature is animated as a swordbreaker skeleton, it retains its statistics except as described below.

entries.name: Type
entries: The skeleton's type changes to undead, and it no longer requires air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The skeleton's alignment changes to lawful evil.

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: The creature has a natural armor class of 13 + its Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: The skeleton's Intelligence score is reduced to 6 ({@d20 -2}), if it was higher, otherwise it retains its Intelligence score. Its Wisdom score changes to 8 ({@d20 -1}), and its Charisma score changes to 5 ({@d20 -3}).

entries.name: Damage Vulnerabilities
entries: The skeleton is vulnerable to thunder damage.

entries.name: Damage Resistances
entries: The skeleton has resistance to piercing and slashing damage.

entries.name: Damage Immunities
entries: The skeleton is immune to poison damage.

entries.name: Condition Immunities
entries: The skeleton is immune to {@condition exhaustion} and the {@condition poisoned} and {@condition petrified} conditions.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The skeleton gains {@sense darkvision} with a radius of 60 feet.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The skeleton understands all languages it knew in life but it can't speak.

entries.name: New Trait: Fossilized Bones
entries: Any nonmagical slashing or piercing weapon made of metal or wood that hits the swordbreaker skeleton cracks. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal or wood that hits the swordbreaker skeleton is destroyed after dealing damage.

trait.name: Four-Legged Lope
entries: When the vexxeh uses its action to {@action Dash}, it moves at three times its speed.

trait.name: Weak Willed
entries: The vexxeh has disadvantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vexxeh makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. If both claw attacks hit the same target, the target and each creature within 5 feet of the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn as the vexxeh cackles with sadistic glee.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

This bestial creature would stand over 15 feet tall if erect but is more comfortable crouched with its knuckles resting on the ground. It wears a pair of trousers and a vest, both obviously made for someone much smaller than it. Its cunning eyes belie a malignant intelligence.

entries.name: Bound to Service
entries: Though they are not devils, vexxeh are natives of the Hells. Their susceptibility to magical domination makes them ideal lieutenants for evil spellcasters. Once a vexxeh has agreed to serve a master, it adheres to the letter of the agreement that has been struck and refuses to break the contract even under the threat of destruction.

entries.name: Lovers of Carnage
entries: Vexxeh only know joy when they are harming living creatures. They relish battle, enjoying the opportunity to shed blood and break bones. More than combat, however, vexxeh enjoy torturing mortals, especially if there is no purpose to it. The psychic distress and trauma suffered by the victims of their torture makes vexxeh gleeful.

entries.name: Fiendishly Polite
entries: Despite their love of violence, vexxeh are unfailingly polite. They mimic the etiquette and social norms of their current master's culture, going so far as to affect mannerisms of nobility. Even when rending a creature into bloody chunks, a vexxeh acts regretful and apologetic.

trait.name: Disease Eater
entries: The viiret is immune to disease, and it has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if the creature is {@condition poisoned} or suffering from a disease.

trait.name: Disease Sense
entries: The viiret can pinpoint, by scent, the location of {@condition poisoned} creatures or creatures suffering from a disease within 60 feet of it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The viiret makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, and it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the viiret. At the start of each of the viiret's turns, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage. If the creature is {@condition poisoned} or suffering from a disease, it takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage at the start of each of the viiret's turns instead. In addition, at the start of each of the viiret's turns, a swallowed creature that is {@condition poisoned} or suffering from a disease can repeat the condition or disease's saving throw as if it had taken a long rest, but it suffers no ill effects on a failed saving throw. The creature has advantage on this saving throw. The viiret can have only one creature swallowed at a time.

If the viiret takes 10 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the viiret must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or regurgitate the swallowed creature, which falls {@condition prone} within 5 feet of the viiret. Alternatively, the viiret can regurgitate the creature as a bonus action, which it does if the swallowed creature isn't {@condition poisoned} or suffering from a disease and a creature that is {@condition poisoned} or suffering from a disease is within 60 feet of the viiret. If the viiret dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape by using 10 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Vine
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
The mouth of this massive flytrap hangs limply, and the smell of decay emanates strongly from it.

entries.name: Disease Eater
entries: Viirets feed on diseased flesh and plant matter. The swamplands they inhabit are rife with maladies, giving them plenty of opportunity to find food. Viirets have an acute sense for diseased matter, regardless of the disease's source. While they aren't bothered by eating untainted prey, such prey isn't as nutritionally satisfying. Their stomachs quickly burn through healthy prey, leaving the viiret hungry shortly afterward.

entries.name: Unpleasant Odor
entries: The viiret has developed a form of mimicry where its sickly odor deters healthy creatures from approaching it. The viiret is even repellent to most insects.

entries.name: Desperate Cure
entries: Marshland societies aware of the viirets' ability to remove disease often view the plants as agents of harsh deities that demand a price for divine gifts. These societies send plague victims on dangerous pilgrimages to find the plants. The plants devour these pilgrims and remove diseased flesh. This process is dangerous, as many who enter the plant hopeful of eliminating the disease die as a result of the injuries they suffer. To mitigate this, multiple ill people travel together to viirets, optimistic the plants will expel newly healthy specimens in favor of a sickly one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (2/Day)
headerEntries: The vine drake can innately cast {@spell entangle}, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is {@footnote Charisma|Spell save {@dc 13}.}.

trait.name: Speak with Plants
entries: The drake can communicate with plants as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Thorn Body
entries: A creature that touches the drake or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vine drake can make three attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and one with its vine lash.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) poison damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Vine Lash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the vine drake can't vine lash another target.

action.name: Acid Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The vine drake exhales acid in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Grasping vines form this draconic creature's wings. Nettle-like teeth fill its maw, and its tail branches like a thriving plant.

entries.name: Living Vines
entries: Vines coil around and branch out from the body of the vine drake, and lengthy thorns protrude from its head and down its spine. The poison dripping from its fangs causes a severe rash on its victims. The drake uses the vines around its body to hide in its swampy home and to squeeze the life out of its prey. Despite the vine drake's plantlike nature, it is still a carnivorous dragon. It prefers deer and other game animals, but it has no problem eating the odd humanoid when it is truly hungry. In the absence of food, it can subsist, though barely, on sunlight if it spends time sunbathing.

entries.name: Avaricious Bullies
entries: Vine drakes share the typical greed possessed by most dragons and often shake down humanoids for treasure in return for safe passage through the drakes' territory. They prefer emeralds and other green precious items that blend with their coloration, and they often secret such items deep within the tangle of vines on their bodies. They usually initiate their demands by grabbing unsuspecting victims in their vines and then threatening to strangle their captured prey unless given green treasures. However, they balk at strong resistance and withdraw into undergrowth if grievously harmed or if they face opponents they can't overcome.

entries.name: Flightless Dragons
entries: Unlike most dragons, vine drakes can't fly. In their claustrophobic swampy lairs, flight is not necessary. Instead, they use their grasping vines to quickly climb and move from tree to tree to hunt or evade predators.

monster.name: Vine Golem

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Bound
entries: The vine golem is psychically bound to its creator and can communicate telepathically with its creator as long as neither is {@condition incapacitated}. In addition, each knows the distance to and direction of the other. The golem and its creator don't have to be on the same plane of existence to communicate telepathically, but they do have to be on the same plane to know each other's distance and direction.

trait.name: Creator's Eyes and Ears
entries: As a bonus action, the creator can see through the vine golem's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of the creator's next turn, gaining the benefits of the vine golem's {@sense darkvision}. During this time, the creator is {@condition deafened|phb|deaf} and {@condition blinded|phb|blind} with regard to its own senses. While using the construct's senses, the creator can cast a spell through the vine golem, using those senses to target the spell. The range, area, and effect of the spell are calculated as if the spell originated from the vine golem, not the master, though the master must still cast the spell on the master's turn. Spells that require concentration must be maintained by the master.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The vine golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The vine golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The vine golem has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks it makes in any terrain that contains ample obscuring plant life.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vine golem makes two thorned vine attacks.

action.name: Thorned Vine
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 10 feet toward the vine golem.

action.name: Thorned Embrace
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the vine golem can't embrace another target.
A humanoid-shaped tangle of green vines shambles through a portal and gives a friendly wave.

entries.name: Druid Servants
entries: Vine golems are constructs created by druids for use as scouts and guardians. These plant-like constructs maintain a psychic connection with their creators, who can see through their eyes and cast spells through them. The golem-creator connection is maintained across the planes of the multiverse and is severed only if the construct or the druid dies. The vine golem is made from a variety of rare plants and flowers found only in the depths of old-growth forests.
